etymologies: late 19th century. From Japanese orihon from ori- + hon book (from Middle Chinese)

definitions: A book formed by folding a scroll alternately backwards and forwards, the resulting concertina-shaped volume then being fastened with cord passed through holes made down one side, and usually enclosed in heavy covers.

notes.text: Orihon were first produced in Japan in the 12th century and were especially used for Buddhist texts.
